title: Blanche d'Alpuget on a life in books after Bob Hawke
text:
Nicole Abadee Jul 17, 2019 — 12.00am Share

What are you reading at the moment? Are books providing some comfort?

Historical fiction. I’m so raw, emotionally, that I can’t read contemporary fiction because so much of it is dystopian and I can’t cope with dystopian ideas right now. I am reading The Cadfael Chronicles by Ellis Peters, a series set in the 12th century about a monk who solves mysteries. They are soothing – like comfort food.

I am also reading Tales of the Dervishes by Idries Shah, an anthology of Sufi teaching stories, and Dark Night of the Soul by 16th-century Spanish poet and mystic St John of the Cross, about spiritual awakening.

Your most recent books, Birth of the Plantagenets, are set in the 12th century. Where did that interest come from?

I think I must have lived then in another life. It was a phenomenal period of civilisation. There was a great flowering of culture, particularly music and architecture, as well as the troubadour poets.

I have read a lot about that period and the characters that really jump out at you are Henry and Eleanor. They were magnificent creatures. I highly recommend Henry II by W.L. Warren and Eleanor of Aquitaine by Alison Weir.

Before you wrote your prize-winning novel Winter in Jerusalem, you read the Bible from cover to cover. Why?

Because I knew that if you don’t know the Bible, you can’t begin to understand Israel. I don’t recommend reading it all in one hit, though. It’s too overwhelming – like eating a whole cow at one meal. It gave me serious psychic, spiritual and mental indigestion.

In your first public statement after your husband’s death, you quoted from the Bible, saying, “the golden bowl is broken”. What did you mean?

That is a quote from Ecclesiastes about life and death. You’ve got to know some of the original Hebrew to understand it. It says, “If the silver chain be loosed, and the golden bowl be broken,” and it’s referring to a light hanging on a silver chain, over a golden bowl, which holds the oil that keeps the light burning. If the chain breaks, the bowl will break and the light will be extinguished. I re-read passages from the Bible quite often. One of my favourites is from Genesis. It says, “And Jacob was left alone and a man wrestled with him until the breaking of the day." It sounds boring, but it’s the wrestle with the angel, and the breaking of the day is the awakening of consciousness. That is my guiding light; you have to keep wrestling with the angel, your spiritual nature, until it reveals the higher truths.

Were you always a big reader?
description: The author of Winter in Jerusalem, and widow of Bob Hawke, on digesting the Bible and her latest instalment in the Birth of the Plantagenets series.
